title: 103_hr2307
content: The Workers' Political Rights Act limits contributions and expenditures by labor organizations. The Workers' Political Rights Act limits contributions and expenditures by labor organizations. Amendments to the Federal Election Campaign Act include requiring political committees to disclose contributions and exempting labor organizations from certain requirements unless specific conditions are met. Labor organizations must provide written notification to employees annually and within 30 days of employment. The Workers' Political Rights Act requires labor organizations to inform employees that they cannot be forced to pay for the organization's political activities. Employees can choose to pay an agency fee instead of joining the organization. The Workers' Political Rights Act mandates that labor organizations must inform employees that they have the option to pay an agency fee instead of joining the organization. The agency fee is limited to the employee's share of the organization's representation services and can be reduced for political activities. The labor organization must provide an annual financial examination by an independent accountant to verify spending on certain expenses. This examination must adhere to auditing standards. The labor organization must maintain procedures to determine costs chargeable to agency fee payors for exclusive representation. They must provide an impartial decision maker for challenges to these costs, subject to review by the National Labor Relations Board or a court. Amounts in dispute must be placed in escrow. Labor organizations must finance expenditures only with funds collected under the Act for their separate segregated fund. Communications advocating for or against a candidate must comply with specific requirements. The amendments made by section 2 of this Act will apply to contributions and expenditures made after the enactment date.
